[h1]Action! - Lights, Camera, Screen Capture Magic![/h1]

[h2]Rating: ★★★★★[/h2]

Using Action! is like being your own director in the blockbuster movie of your digital adventures. It's a screen capture tool that turns your gaming triumphs and hilarious fails into Oscar-worthy moments. Forget Spielberg; your gameplay is now the star of the show, and Action! is your trusty behind-the-scenes wizard.

[h3]Pros:[/h3]

1. [b]User-Friendly Interface:[/b] Action! boasts an interface so user-friendly, even your grandma could record her epic Minesweeper victories. It's like a director's chair designed for gamers of all skill levels.

2. [b]High-Quality Recording:[/b] The recording quality is like capturing your screen in 4K glory. Your gameplay shines brighter than a supernova, making those headshots and epic escapes look even more impressive.

3. [b]Real-Time Streaming:[/b] With real-time streaming capabilities, Action! turns your gaming sessions into live performances. It's like having your own virtual theater where your audience cheers for every triumph and chuckles at every mishap.

4. [b]Rich Editing Features:[/b] The editing features are like a digital Swiss Army knife. Cut, splice, add effects—Action! lets you turn your raw footage into a cinematic masterpiece without needing a degree in film production.

5. [b]Broad Format Support:[/b] Action! supports more formats than a Netflix binge-watching marathon. Whether you're into MP4, AVI, or the more exotic formats, this tool has you covered.

[h3]Cons:[/h3]

1. [b]Premium Features at a Cost:[/b] The full suite of features comes with a price tag. While the free version offers a taste, serious content creators may find themselves reaching for their wallets for the full experience.

2. [b]Resource Intensive:[/b] Action! can be a bit of a diva when it comes to system resources. Older rigs might struggle to keep up, leading to potential frame drops and lag.

3. [b]Learning Curve for Advanced Features:[/b] Unlocking the full potential of Action! requires a bit of tutorial time. Delving into the more advanced features is like entering the director's cut, and it might take some experimenting.

4. [b]Occasional Bugs:[/b] Like any production, Action! has its occasional blooper reel. Users might encounter bugs or glitches, though frequent updates aim to keep the show running smoothly.

5. [b]Limited Audio Editing:[/b] While the video editing is robust, the audio editing capabilities are more like a supporting actor than the leading star. Advanced audio editing enthusiasts might crave a bit more functionality.

[h3]Conclusion:[/h3]

Action! is the Spielberg of screen recording, turning your gaming moments into blockbuster hits. With its user-friendly interface and powerful features, it's a must-have tool for anyone looking to elevate their gaming content creation.

And it’s not just the ease of recording, the software enables you to upload your gameplay directly to your YouTube channel. Now that's what I call a two-birds-with-one-stone solution!

Let's also howl at the moon about its groundbreaking Time Shift system! It's like that magical portal in those animes that takes you back in time. This feature allows you to record only the action you wish to highlight without having to record the entire sequence, thereby saving a lot of storage space and effort. Action is a game recorder, it is a general screen recording and gameplay recording software, one of the most popular on the market. Allows real-time recording and streaming, all in high definition. Action! It allows users to record smooth, high frame rate videos of any desktop and action, add audio commentary and even create easy-to-follow tutorials without any hassle. With an intuitive user interface and integration with popular streaming services, Action! is one of the easiest to use screen recorders available.

Action! It is compatible with Windows Vista, 7, 8, 8.1 and Windows 10 and 11, making it available to the vast majority of gamers and other performance users. Videos recorded with Action! are saved as AVI 2.0 or MP4 using H.264 or H.265 codecs. This means users get the best of both worlds: smaller file size and better quality. On a single screen, Action! can record video in any quality up to 4K. Three-dimensional gameplay, however, can be recorded in AVI format up to 8192x8192, surpassing most modern video recording qualities. When recording video in AVI format, Action! can capture up to 120 frames per second. In the highest quality MP4 format, Action! can record up to 60 frames per second.

Action! it's packed with features. It uses your GPU in the most optimized way to ensure smooth recording of high-definition games and can display your current and average frame rate while playing to save your benchmark results. Action! Perhaps player-centric, but it didn't leave other users behind. With high definition and smooth recording of any action performed on the screen, this powerful program can help any user to record high quality tutorials with ease. Even if you switch windows, Action! will continue to record to a solid clip. You can also add live mic audio commentary for complete ease of use.

Action! it is also very adept at live streaming and is integrated with popular streaming services like Twitch, Facebook Live, YouTube and Hitbox. If you're not live streaming but would like to share your clips, Action! has several preset profiles that allow you to simply push a button and instantly export your clips to the format that will work for your media platform of choice.
The “Games and Applications” recording mode is designed to capture video from any DirectX 9/10/11 or OpenGL game or application. The HUD will be displayed in the upper right corner of your game. The blue color of the frame rate numbers indicates the game is active and Action! is ready to record.

The default hotkey to start game recording is F9. Hit this once you're ready to record and play as you normally would. You can tell the game is being recorded because of the HUD changes. When you're ready to stop recording, press F9 again. Your recording will end and the HUD will return to its normal state. If you don't want the HUD to show up in your recordings, make sure you join Action! HUD Options and select “Do not record HUD in games and apps”. To play videos you've recorded, you can use Action's built-in player! to select game recording. For more playback options, consider downloading Splash, also made by Mirillis. With Splash, you get access to powerful features like SmartSeek, DetailBoost, LightBoost and AudioBoost.

Conclusion:

While it may not be without its shortcomings, Action! is one of the best screen capture software available for game recording/streaming or general screen capture. The user interface is intuitive and the recording tools are powerful. It offers smoother recordings than others on the market and is reasonably priced. I recommend its purchase, for those who are interested in recording their gameplays, I was very satisfied recording my gameplays. I recommend!

Action Vs OBS LIVE (STREAMING/RECORDING)

Action is much more ui friendly compared to obs live and is simple set up for the on the go streamer, as well as that has partial stream element widget/overlay compatibility.

OBS Live has many more options, and may require you to tweak many options manually that Action would do for you automatically, in order to get your stream up successfully - however OBS live has full compatibility with streamelements and streamlabs widgets/overlays. 

Most people would recommend OBS Live however both of these are good alternatives to each other with the addition of using streamelements & other streaming tools to help enhance the quality of your stream or video. 

As such i recommend, Action for normal gameplay recording and other use - whereas OBS live is more fit for live streaming.

1. There is no game profile setup, still. Meaning, every time you record another game with your webcam on, you have to manually set up the volume and the positioning of the webcam window.

Alright, so, I can honestly say with the amount of time I have in this software, that I've seen it's ups and downs.

First, I'll go against the grind and do the cons first.

[h1] The Bad Stuff [/h1]

For one, there's a small, possibly non-fixable gripe I have with the software myself; it's honestly something that should be the LAST priority on the dev team's list. There's simply a limit on the 'area' recording, that makes recording specific parts of a video hard to do. But, that's a VERY easy fix with an editing software; remember, if you buy this, you bought a recording software, not an editing tool.

Another gripe of mine is that every once in a while, there's a very serious bug that tends to break specific parts of the software. This is not often, but I used to not be able to record in the first place with AVI, and it used to throttle my video recording, or speed it up far too much. This has happened 3-5 times. I won't lie, one time, my entire software was broken, and it's my duty to tell you I had to download the beta in order to fix it.

Another potential problem with the software, is it's massive AVI video sizes. As stated by someone else, about 5 minutes of footage on an AVI video is about 1 gig, give or take. However, that might just be normal, as I don't understand enough in that field to know, and on that record, it can be fixed by switching to MP4 instead.

[h1] The Gray Area [/h1]

A rather gray area is that the developers don't update quite as much as they used to. But that COULD mean there's less bugs, but I don't entirely know. It could also mean they depend on the community to fix it; it's a gray area since I haven't done proper research and have only really noticed this through my downloads.

As you can tell, I haven't mentioned anything about streaming; I myself am not a streamer, and cannot speak on it.

Now we get into the fun part; the good stuff! The stuff that really sells the software!

[h1] The Good Stuff [/h1]

For one, it's far more reliable than it has been in years, at least for me. Over the time, as said before, it has been pretty hectic. But it seems pretty stable nowadays. Though, to tie in with the gray area, I have not done my research on whether others have lots of problems with it.

For one, the software has a 'preview mode', so you can see how the screen and your webcam look before you record, so you don't look like a doofus like me when you start recording.

Now, this may seem like an essential, and I'm sure it is, but for a long time, they didn't even have this feature. but you can now adjust the size of your webcam picture, in the previously stated menu. This can make it worse quality, I'm sure, but in the end, at least people will be able to see your features.

Recording files are generally nice to look at, at least in my case. They're never too small, or difficult to view, as long as the graphics on your screen and game are okay; it records directly from your screen, so usually whatever you see, they see. It can also be set to 1080p, 720p, 480p, 360p, and 240p.

I've been using this program off an on for a couple years now. It consistently sees updates, even now, and for my money, it is probably the most consistent and easy to use game capture program I own. I don't necessarily think it's spectacular, as it is a bit basic, but that actually holds a lot of appeal for me. I don't want to have to struggle to use a capture program, and this one is about as user friendly as it gets.

For one, I don't typically notice much if any drop in FPS or performance while running this parallel to whatever game I'm recording. The actual UI in game is as simple as F9 to start and stop recording, with other options for screenshots and such. I don't feel like it really compresses the recording file well on the front end, and transferring videos from here to YT or wherever does take a bit longer than would be optimal, but it does do a decent job of compressing the files during transfer.

There are quite a few options for how you prefer to record, at different resolutions and formats, and provides a lot of support for people who prefer to dive in more deeply, offering plenty of options to really dial in and fine tune your recordings.

I don't live stream, so I can't speak to that, but it is an option as well.

All in all, I tend to feel like most capture programs are a bit overrated and overpriced, but I had no issues paying what was then half price for this one. I'd definitely recommend this program while it's on sale, although I do think the base asking price is steep. For me, it's the primary capture program I use though, and as you can see from my hours put into it, it definitely has provided excellent value.

I've used Action! for a long time now. First tried the trial version, then decided to buy it once it came on sale in Steam for 50% off

Action is a good game capture AND screen recording program. I can't emphasize on the screen recording, as some of the game capture programs cannot capture other windows or desktop (Fraps for instance). You can save the file either in MP4 where the file size is small as it compresses it, but you might have game performance suffer a bit from it. If you don't want any game performance issues, you can also record on AVI which saves the uncompressed version (which means large file size but helps a lot when video editing).

The quality fo the video can be determined well. From 15 to 120 FPS, from 360p to 1080p... You have a lot of options to choose from. The sound quality is good, too, though I do remind people that ify ou pick up multiple track recording, you can't hear multiple audio channels normally in media players. You have to video edit it in Adobe Premiere Pro to see all tracks. This is one of my suggestions to the developers: Make it an option that the audio tracks are saved as their own files.

I haven't tried the streaming function as I find it obsolete since I have OBS. I don't think they can get to OBS's levels of stream functions unless they really want to try to focus on it.

Overall, from many game capture programs I've tried (Dxtory, D3DGear, Bandicam, Radeon ReLive, OBS, Fraps) Action is my go-to program, for its quality, and if recording uncompressed, has little to no impact on the game's performance.


+ Little to no impact on gameplay if uncompressed
+ Little file size if recording compressed
+ Streaming function
+ Multiple audio track
+ Can capture desktop or any window.

- No option to save audio separately
- Compressed recording might have impact on game performance

Mrillis Action!, is a screen recorder that gives you high quality videos and a stylish, easy to use interface. The layout is simple and easy to use, while still having everything you would want in a screen recorder. It has 3 modes: "Gaming mode", which, as the title would suggest, is best for recording gaming videos. "Active Screen" or "Windowed mode" which records your entire desktop screen, unlike Gaming Mode which only records the game window. And then "Active Desktop Region." This mode is mainly used if you want to target and record a specific area on your screen.

This screen recorder also has built in audio recording and snapshotting abilities, which can come in handy.

This screen recorder isn't perfect, so let's get into some of its cons. 

1. Sometimes while trying to record a specific game, (Minecraft for instance) the big red "record" button is greyed out and you are unable to click on it. So you are forced to just use the hotkey "F9" to start and stop the recording. However, this can become tedious, at least for me. I for one have had a few experiences where I accidently pressed the wrong button and I didn't record. And although a lot of people don't think being forced to use the hotkey is a bad thing, I personally wish I could press the button instead for certain situations. I'm not sure if this is for all games or not, but this has happened for quite a few games before. 

2. Sometimes the start and stop recording hotkey is unresponsive. Often when you start a recording then stop it, then start it again, it won't start the second time and you are left talking to yourself in your house and you gained no recording. Its really a let down when you have been recording for an hour and then you look back and it hasn't been recording at all. This is another reason I wish I could just press the red button to start the recordings and that it wasn't all greyed out for some reason. 

3. If your game crashes while you are recording, that video file becomes corrupted and you cannot view it. This really blows and is one of the main reasons I stopped using bandicam and switched to Action, because bandicam did the same thing. However, it appears Action has the same problem. I really wish when the game crashed the recording would continue on, but be a black screen instead, or perhaps would just stop the recording. But instead if your game crashes you lose that recording, which is very dissapointing. 

4. The price. I know this isn't exactly a strong con, but I should mention that this recorder costs $49.99. Not a terrible price to pay for a screen recorder, but still pretty expensive. I'd recommend waiting until there's a sale and pick it up for maybe $40 or $35.  

And that's all I can really think of for cons at the moment. 

So:

Cons: 
1. Can't click the starting and stopping button on some games.
2. Start and stop recording hotkey is sometimes unresponsive. 
3. If your game crashes while you are recording, you lose that recording. 
4. Its a bit pricey. 

Pros: 
1. Stylish Interface that is easy to use while still providing all the necessary settings you would need for a screen recorder.
2. High quality videos.
3. Multiple recording options 
4. Audio and snapshotting abilities.
5. Stable.

Overall I would definitely recommend this software, especially if you are a youtuber like myself. Its easy to use and really doesn't dissapoint too much. It has its problems, but personally I feel the pros outweigh the cons. 
Its a very handy application that you should get even if you are not a youtuber. However, i'd advise picking it up during a sale. 

Thanks for reading! :)

I've had it for a while now, and I can say that while it has it's flaws, it is definitely a solid recorder. It can record games at 1080p if you want (and can). I will mention that there is an original option in the quality options, which is for recording at a resolution that isn't 1080p, 720p, 480p, 360p or 240p. It will not record higher than 1080p though. If you are playing a game at 1080p, and you set it to record at 720p, it will only record at that resolution. This is a fantastic feature because, while it may look a bit blurry (and i mean a TINY bit), it will come out as a much smaller file. Which is good if you don't own a very big hard drive or want to upload something to Youtube in your lifetime. This recording option can be done in any of the listed resolutions. This feature is lacking in several big recording softwares, which force people to manually compress the files. 

The UI is fantastic, and way more straight forward than most recorders that I have used before. The recording options are easy to reach, and yet they seem to do a lot without being confusing. There are SO many features that I love about this software that I can't find in most recorders. There's a window option, where you can record a certain part of your screen, which is very handy for windowed games. There's a facecam option if you have a camera. And of course, it has the usual voice recording options.You can choose for it to limit your frame rate while you are recording, which is good if you don't want lag or just simply want to record at a certain FPS. Action also performs WAAAAYYY better than FRAPS. The recording quality is definitely grainy, but it's worth it for the better framerate, and while some people may want to go for the recorder that records a tiny bit better, Action won't dive on the frame rate.

When I used FRAPS to play a retro game, I got about 5 FPS, and the game even FROZE at times. Even when I wasn't recording, having it open slowed the game down.  With Action, the game ran like it did when I wasn't recording. It was incredible how fast it ran. One complaint I have, is the FPS options I mentioned earlier. You can chose to limit your frame rate at 60, 50, 30, 25, 24 (yes 24), 20, 15, and 120. Why are the options so random? Why is there a 25 and 24 option? There's no difference! And yet there's no 40 FPS option. I actually really like limiting my frame rate at 40. So why am I stuck with using 25, 24 and 15? Get rid of 24, as a single frame difference is NOTHING, and add 40.

EDIT: After a long time of use, I have noticed how much of a lottery it is when it comes to audio. Sometimes the recording has tinny, echoing sound, which really sticks out like a nose unless if you mask it with music in editing. Other times, however, it records perfectly fine.

IMPORTANT: To do live streams, you need a subscription. It comes with a free subscription when you buy it, but I can't remember how long it is. I have never streamed using Action, so don't ask me how it performs. I really want to emphasise that there are programs like OBS (Open Broadcaster Software) that can not only record games, but also stream them FOR FREE. Not to mention you can also add on screen pictures and messages in real time on OBS. So if you want to do live streams, seriously consider something else.

Basically the game is loading one sequence after the next, switching from scenes to action combat all the time.

That cause my recording to crash over and over and over as that was the issue I had with the initial loading screen in 7 Days to Die too but unlike Shadow or Mordor, 7DTD does not have any more loading screens during the game so I never realised the bigger picture of the problem.

So, what have I tried?

[b]With MP4 without AMD APP on 720p[/b]

I choose to only record in MP4 and not AVI or MP4 with AMD APP it doesn't crash during the loading screens then but I can only record in 720p but hey,..better than crashing..

This looked great at first as now the recording didn't crash.....

[b]However[/b], the recording quality then was just awful, the sound goes all over the shop. Speed changes of the sound track and you end up with a clip where the video channel is longer than the sound channels due to the speed changes. Now, what next....?

I switch back to MP4 with AMD APP and 1080p and worked out that when I un-check "use multicore recording" that it also doesn't crash any more during loading sequences. 

Awesome. 1080p no crash and back to normal.

...NO now I also get the same problem with the sound, which changes speed and the quality is pure rubbish.

[b]With MP4 with AMD APP on 1080p and multicore unchecked[/b]

When I record in MP4 with AMD APP on 1080p [b]with "use multicore recording" checked[/b] the quality of the sound is brilliant and the video quality is too but then I get the issue that the application stops recording when ever any type of loading sequence occurs.

[b]Summary[/b]
So, to that end it seems that I either record with perfect sound and image quality and all the bells and whistle work amazingly well [b]but[/b] have to manually re-start recording between loading screens which is a pain in the a$$, specially if you have a dynamic game like Shadow of Mordor I can record in rubbish quality with loads of sound issues but don't crash.
